assertion.description: The URI for the core tag library must be http://java.sun.com/jsp/jstl/core.
The URI for the XML processing tag library must be http://java.sun.com/jsp/jstl/xml.
The URI for the 18N capable formatting tag library must be http://java.sun.com/jsp/jstl/fmt.
The URI for the relational database access (SQL) tag library must be http://java.sun.com/jsp/jstl/sql.
The URI for the functions tag library must be http://java.sun.com/jsp/jstl/functions.
The URI for the RT-based core tags must be http://java.sun.com/jstl/core-rt
The URI for the RT-based XML processing tags must be http://java.sun.com/jstl/xml-rt
The URI for the RT-based I18N capable formatting tags must be http://java.sun.com/jstl/fmt-rt
The URI for the RT-based relational database access (SQL) tags must be http://java.sun.com/jstl/sql-rt
An attribute value can accept a static String.
Nested scoped variables are only visible within the body of the action and are stored in page scope.
The action must create the variable as if by calling PageContext.setAttribute(varName, PAGE_SCOPE).
The action must remove the variable at the end of the action as if by calling PageContext.removeAttribute(varName, PAGE_SCOPE)
At-end scoped variables are only visible at the end of the action and their lifecycle is one associated with their associated scope.
Attributes of actions may accept dynamic values (EL or RT depending on the tag) except for attributes describing 'scope' and attributes that export variables via 'var' and/or 'varXXX' attributes.
Valid whitespace characters are #x20, #x9, #xD, or #xa per the JSP specification as well as the XML and XSLT specifications.
An empty body is always valid for actions accepting a body content.
Body content is used to set the value of an attribute, then an empty body content sets the attribute value to an empty string.
Body content is trimmed prior to being processed by the action, it is trimmed as defined by the method trim() of the java class java.lang.String
All syntax errors (as defined by the syntax section of each action) must be reported at translation time.

Constraints, as defined in the constraints section of each action, must also be reported at translation time unless they operate on a dynamic attribute value, in which case errors are reported at runtime.
Semantics of handling errors and exceptions are defined as follows:
If 'scope' is provided an invalid value a translation time validation error must occur.
If 'var' or 'varXXX' is empty, a translation time validation error must occur.
Dynamic attributes with a fixed set of valid values will handle errors as follows:
If the value is null, use the default value.
If the value is invalid, throw an exception.
Dynamic attributes without a fixed set of valid values will handle errors as follows:
If the value is null, the behavior is specific to the action.
If the value is of an invalid type, throw an exception.
If the value is invalid, throw an exception.
Exceptions caused by the body content must be propagated.
Exceptions caused by the action itself must be propagated.
Exceptions caused by the EL must be propagated.
An exception thrown by an action must be an instance or subclass of 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.JspException'.
If an action catches any exceptions that occur in its body, its tag handler must provide the caught exception as the root cause of the JspException it re-throws.
Exceptions caused by XPath are always propagated.

When a configuration parameter can be specified either as a scoped variable or a context parameter, scoped variables are searched first according to the semantics defined for method findAttribute(String name) of the JSP class jakarta.servlet.jsp.PageContext. If the value is not found, then method getInitParameter(String name) is called on the servlet context associated with the web application to try to get the value of the configuration parameter from a context initialization parameter.
When setting configuration data via the deployment descriptor, the name associated with the context initialization parameter must be used and only String values may be specified.

If the type of the object used as the value of a configuration variable does not match one of those supported by the configuration variable, conversion is performed according to the conversion rules defined in the expression language.
A failure of these conversion rules to determine an appropriate type coersion leads to a JspException at runtime.
The values of the static members of the jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.core.Config class are as follows:
assertion.comment: These values are taken from the javadoc.

assertion.description: The value of Config.FMT_FALLBACK_LOCALE is "jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.fallbackLocale".
The value of Config.FMT_LOCALE is "jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.locale".
The value of Config.FMT_LOCALIZATION_CONTEXT is "jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.localizationContext".
The value of Config.FMT_TIME_ZONE is "jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.timeZone".
The value of Config.SQL_DATA_SOURCE is "jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.sql.dataSource".
The value of Config.SQL_MAX_ROWS is "jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.sql.maxRows".

The lookup of configuration variables is performed as if each scope had its own name space, that is, the same configuration variable name in one scope does not replace one stored in a different scope.
assertion.comment: Description is taken from the javadoc for Config.get().

assertion.description: Setting the value of a configuration variable is performed as if each scope had its own name space, that is, the same configuration variable name in one scope does not replace one stored in a different scope.
assertion.comment: Description is taken from the javadoc for Config.set().

assertion.description: The lookup of configuration variables is performed as if each scope had its own name space, that is, the same configuration variable name in one scope does not replace one stored in a different scope.
assertion.comment: Description is taken from the javadoc for Config.remove().

assertion.description: The jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.core.Config.find() method finds the value associated with a specific configuration setting identified by its context initialization parameter name.
assertion.comment: Description is taken from the javadoc for Config.find().

assertion.description: If no value is found, the method attempts to find the value of the context initialization parameter identified by name.
The EL is invoked exclusively via the construct ${expr}.
Attributes can contain more than one EL expression, mixed with static text.

An identifier in the EL refers to a JSP scoped variable returned by a call to PageContext.getAttribute(identifier). Therefore, the variable can reside in any of the four JSP scopes: page, request, session, or application.
A null value is returned of the variable does not exist in any of the scopes.
The EL defines implicit objects to support easy access to application data.
The 'application' implicit object
The 'session' implicit object
The 'request' implicit object
The 'page' implicit object
Access to HTTP Request parameters
The 'param' implicit object is a Map object where param["param-name"] returns the first value associated with the 'param-name'
The 'params' implicit object will return an array of all string values associated with that request parameter (params["param-name"]).
The implicit object 'pageContext'.
The EL provides two operators to provide easy access to data encapsulated in the accessed objects.
The '.' operator provides a convenient shorthand for propety access when the property name follows the conventions of java indentifiers.
The '[]' operator allows more generalized access.
The EL defines operators for relational, arithmetic, and logical operations against data.
Relational Operators: ==, !=, < (or lt), > (or gt), <= (or le), >= (or ge)
Arithmetic Operators: addition (+), subtraction (-), multiplication (*), division (/ or div), and remainder/modulo (% or mod)
Binary Operators: and, or, and not
The <c:out> action evaluates an expression and outputs the result of the evaluation to the current JspWriter object.
The 'value' attribute defines the expression to be evaluated
The result of the expression evaluation must yield an Object type.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type Object and a default value is not provided, either as body content, or as an attribute value, an Exception is thrown.
If the result of the evaluation is not a java.io.Reader object, then it is coerced to a String and is subsequently emitted into the current JspWriter object
If the result of the evaluation is a java.io.Reader object, data is first read from the Reader object and then written into the current JspWriter object.
The 'escapeXml' attribute determines whether the characters <,>,&,'," in the resulting string should be converted to their corresponding character entity codes.
The default value is true.
The result of the evaluated expression must be boolean.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type boolean, an Exception is thrown.
If a value is provided, but invalid, an Exception is thrown.
'<' is converted to \<
'>' is converted to \>
'&' is converted to \&
Single quote (') is converted to &#039.
Double quote (") is converted to &#034.
If the value evaluates to null, the default value, 'true', will be used.
An invalid value will result in an Exception being thrown.
The 'default' attribute specified the value to be used of the value attribute cannot be evaluated, or the resulting value is null.
The result of the evaluated expression must be an Object.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type Object, an Exception is thrown.
If no default value is specified, it itself defaults to an empty string.
An exception will be propagated only if no default value is specified.
A default value for the action can be defined as body content of the action.
The 'value' attribute is required in all syntax variations of the action.
Any exception caused by the body content, if present, must be propagated.
If an exception is caused by the action itself, it must be propagated.
The <c:set> action sets the value of a scoped variable or a property of a target object.
The expression to be evaluated in Syntax 1, 3 and 5 is specified by the attribute 'value'
The result of the expression evaluation must yield an Object type.
The expression to be evaluated in Syntax 2 is specified within the body of the action.
The 'var' attribute defines the name of the exported scoped attribute to hold the value specified in the action in Syntax 1, 2, 5.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The result of the expression evaluation must yield a String type.
If the evaluated expression is not a String, an exception is thrown.
The 'scope' attribute sets the scope of the exported variable in Syntax 1 qnd 2.
A scoped variable can be exported to the 'page' scope
A scoped variable can be exported to the 'request' scope
A scoped variable can be exported to the 'session' scope
A scoped variable can be exported to the 'application' scope
If the scope attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
If the scope attribute is not specified, the default scope of 'page' will be used.
The 'var' attribute is required across all syntax variations of the action.
If 'value' is null:
In Syntax 1, the scoped variable defined by 'var' and 'scope' is removed.
If attribute scope is specified, the scoped variable is removed according to the semantics of PageContext.removeAttribute(varName, scope).

Otherwise, there is no way to differentiate between syntax 1 and syntax 5. The scoped variable is removed according to the semantics of PageContext.removeAttribute(varName), and the variable is removed from the VariableMapper as well.
In Syntax 3, if target is a Map, remove the entry with the key identified by property.
In Syntax 3, if target is a JavaBean component, set the property to null.

In Syntax 5, here is no way to differentiate between syntax 1 (where scope is not specified) and syntax 5. The scoped variable is removed according to the semantics of PageContext.removeAttribute(varName), and the variable is removed from the VariableMapper as well.
If an invalid value is provided to the 'scope' attribute, a translation time validation error must occur.
Any exception caused by the body content, must be propagated.
The target attribute represents the target object whose property will be set in Syntax 3 and 4.
The target attribute must evaluate to a JavaBeans object with setter property property, or to a java.util.Map object.
If the target attribute is null, throw an exception.
If the target attribute is not a java.util.Map object and is not a JavaBeans object that supports setting property 'property', throw an exception.
The property attribute represents the name of the property to be set in the target object in Syntax 3 and 4.
The property attribute must evaluate to a String.
If the property attribute does not evaluate to a String, an exception is thrown.
In Syntax 1, set the value of a the scoped variable identified by 'var' and 'scope' using attribute 'value.'
In Syntax 2, set the value of a the scoped variable identified by 'var' and 'scope' using body content.
In Syntax 3, set a property of a target object using attribute 'value.'
In Syntax 4, set a property of a target object using body content.
In Syntax 3 and 4, if the target expression evaluates to a java.util.Map object, set the value of the element associated with the key identified by 'property.'
If the element does not exist, add it to the Map object.
In Syntax 3 and 4, if the target expression does not evaluate to a java.util.Map object, set the value of the 'property' property of the JavaBeans object 'target.'
If the type of the value to be set does not match the type of the bean property, conversion is performed according to the conversion rules defined in the expression language.
A failure of the conversion rules to determine an appropriate type coercion leads to a JspException at runtime.
Syntax 5 sets a deferred value. The deferred-value specified is mapped to the "var" attribute into the EL VariableMapper.
The <c:remove> action removes a scoped variable.
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the scoped variable to remove.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope of the variable to remove.
A value of 'page' will cause 'var' to be removed from the page scope.
A value of 'request' will cause 'var' to be removed the the request scope.
A value of 'session' will cause 'var' to be removed from the session scope.
A value of 'application' will cause 'var' to be removed from the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
If attribute 'scope' is note specified, the scoped variable is removed by calling PageContext.removeAttribute(varName).
The 'var' attribute is required.
The <c:remove> attribute does not accept a body content.
The <c:catch> action catchs a java.lang.Throwable thrown by any of its nested actions.
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped variable for the exception thrown from a nested action. They type of the scoped variable is the type of the exception thrown.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The body content, consisting of nested actions, is processed by the JSP container and the result is written to the current JspWriter.
If the 'var' attribute is not specified, the exception is simply caught and not saved.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The <c:if> action evaluates its body content if the expression specified with the 'test' attribute is true.
The 'test' attribute specifies the test condition that indicates whether or not the body content should be processed.
If the expression is true, the JSP container processes the body of the action and writes it to the current JspWriter.
If the expression is false, the body of the action is not processed.
The result of the evaluated EL expression must be 'boolean' or 'Boolean'
The result of the evaluated RT expression must be 'boolean'.
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped variable for the resulting value of the test condition.
The type of the exported scoped variable must be 'Boolean'
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute sets the scope of the exported variable.
A scoped variable can be exported to the 'page' scope
A scoped variable can be exported to the 'request' scope
A scoped variable can be exported to the 'session' scope
A scoped variable can be exported to the 'application' scope
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'test' attribute is required.
The action should not have a content body if the 'var' attribute is specified.
If 'var' is specified without specifying a scope, the variable will be exported to the page scope by default.
Any exception caused by the body-content, must be propagated.
The <c:choose> action provides the context for mutually exclusive conditional execution.
The <c:choose> action process the body of the first <c:when> action whose test condition evaluates to true.
The body content of the <c:choose> action can only consist of:
White space may appear anywhere around the <c:when> and <c:otherwise> subtags.
1 or more <c:when> actions, all of which must appear before <c:otherwise>
0 or 1 <c:otherwise> action, which if present, must be the last nested action within <c:choose>
The <c:when> action represents an alternative within a <c:choose> action.
The body content of the first <c:when> action to evaluate to true will be processed and written to the current JspWriter.
The 'test' attriubte describes a test condition which determines whether or not the body content should be processed.
The result of the evaluated EL expression must be 'boolean' or 'Boolean'
The result of the evaluated RT expression must be 'boolean'
The 'test' attribute is required.
The <c:when> action must have <c:choose> as an immediate parent.
The <c:when> action must appear before an <c:otherwise> action that has the same parent.
If an exception is caused by the body-content it must be propagated.
The <c:otherwise> action is used optionally as the last alternative whitin a <c:choose> action.
The body content of <c:otherwise> will be processed and written to the current JspWriter when no <c:when> action evaluated to true.
The <c:otherwise> action must have <c:choose> as an immediate parent.
<c:otherwise> must be the last nested action within <c:choose>
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
The <c:forEach> action repeats its nested body content over a collection of objects or repeats a fixed number of times.
The 'var' attribute represents the name of the exported scoped variable for the current item of the iteration.
The type of the exported variable depends on the underlying collection
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'items' attribute specifies a collection of items to iterate over.
<c:forEach> must support iteration over Arrays
Includes arrays of Objects
Includes arrays of primitive types
The current item for the iteration is automatically wrapped with its standard wrapper class.
<c:forEach> must support iteration over implementations of java.util.Collection
An 'Iterator' object is obtained from the collection vai the iterator() method, and the items of the collection are processed in the order returned by that 'Iterator' object.
<c:forEach> must support iteration over implementations of java.util.Iterator.
Items of the collection are processed in the order returned by the 'Iterator' object.
<c:forEach> must support iteration over implementations of java.util.Enumeration.
Items of the collection are processed in the order returned by the 'Enumeration' object.
<c:forEach> must support iteration over implementations of java.util.Map
Items exposed via the 'var' attribute when iterating over an instance of java.util.Map will be of type java.util.Map.Entry
The 'key' property of the java.util.Map.Entry exposes the name of the key under which this item is stored within the underlying Map.
The 'value' property of the java.util.Map.Entry exposes the value of the item stored in the underlying Map.
A 'Set' view of the mappings is obtained from the map via the entrySet() method, from which an 'Iterator' object is obtained via the iterator() method.
The items of the collection are processed in the order returned by that 'Iterator' object.
<c:forEach> must support iteration over implementations of java.sql.ResultSet.
The object exposed via the 'var' attribute is the ResultSet object itself positioned at the current row.
Rows are processed according to their sequential order in the ResultSet.
<c:forEach> must support iteration over a String representation of a comma-separated list of values, where the comma character is the token delimiter.
Tokens are processed in their sequential order in the String.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type Object.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type Object, an Exception is thrown.
If the 'item's attribute is not specified, the exported object associated with the 'var' attribute is of type Integer.
The 'varStatus' attribute specifies the name of the scoped variable for the status of the iteration
The exported Object associated with the value of the 'varStatus' attribute is of type jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.core.LoopTagStatus.
The 'begin' attribute specifies a starting index value.
If the 'items' attribute is specified, the 'begin' attribute dictates that the iteration begins at the item located at the specified index.
The first item of the collection has index 0.
If the 'items' attribute is not specified, the 'begin' attribute dictates that iteration begins with the index set at the value specified.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'int'.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type 'int'
The 'end' attribute specifies an ending index value.
If the 'items' attribute is specified, the 'ends' attribute dictates that the Iteration ends at the item located at the specified index.
If the 'items' attribute is not specified, the 'end' attribute dictates that iteration ends when the index reaches the value specified.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'int'.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type int, an Exception is thrown.
The 'step' attribute specifies that iteration will only process every 'step' items of the collections, starting with the first.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'int'.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type int, an Exception is thrown.
As long as there are items to iterate over, the body content is processed by the JSP container and written to the current JspWriter.
The body content is not trimmed.
If 'begin' is specified, the value must be >= 0.
If 'step' is specified, step must be >= 1
If 'items' is null, it is treated as an empty collection (no iteration is performed).
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
When a deferred-value is specified for the items attribute, the tag handler now adds at each iteration a mapping for the var attribute into the EL VariableMapper.
If end is specified and it is less than begin, the loop is simply not executed.
The <c:forTokens> tag iterates over tokens, specified by the supplied delimiters.
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped variable for the current item of the iteration.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'items' attribute specifies the String of tokens to iterate over
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'String'.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown
The 'delims' attribute specifies the set of delimiters.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'String'
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type String, an exception is thrown.
The 'varStatus' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped variable for the status of the iteration.
The object exported is of type jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.LoopTagStatus.
The 'begin' attribute specifies the index location at which to begin iteration
The first token has an index of 0.
The result of the evaluated expression must of of type 'int'.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type int, an Exception is thrown.
The 'end' attribute specifies the index location at which to stop the iteration.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'int'.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type int, an Exception is thrown.
The 'step' attribute specifies that iteration will only process every 'step' tokens of the String, starting with the first one.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'int'.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type int, an Exception is thrown.
As long as there are items to iterate over, the body content is processed by the JSP container and written to the current JspWriter.
The body content is not trimmed
The 'items' attribute is required.
The 'delims' attribute is required.
The tokens of the String are retrieved as defined by the creation of a java.util.StringTokenizer object with arguments items (the string to be tokenized) and delims (the delimiters).
If 'begin' is specified, the value must be >= 0.
If 'end' is specified, 'end' must be >= 'begin'.
If 'step' is specified, it must be >= 1.
If 'items' is null, it is treated as en empty collection (no iteration).
If 'delims' is null, 'items' is treated as a single monolithic token. Thus, when 'delims' is null, <c:forTokens> iterates exactly zero (if 'items' is also null') or one time.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
If end is specified and it is less than begin, the loop is simply not executed.
When a deferred-value is specified for the items attribute, the tag handler now adds at each iteration a mapping for the var attribute into the EL VariableMapper.
The <c:import> action imports the content of a URL-based resource.
The 'url' attribute specifies the URL of the resource to import.
The 'url' attribute must be able to accept relative URLs as defined by the JSP specification.
A relative URL can be a context-relative path which starts with a '/' and is interpreted as relative to the application to which the JSP page belongs.
A relative URL can be a page-relative path which does not start with a '/' and is interpreted as relative to the current JSP page.
The semantics of importing a resource specified with a relative URL in the same context are the same as an include performed by a RequestDispatcher.
The whole enviroment (request, session, application) of the importing page is available to the target resource (including request parameters of the importing page).
The 'url' attribute must be able to accept relative URLs of a foreign context within the same container.
The relative URL specified must be a context-relative path (starts with a '/').
The semantics of importing a resource specified with a relative URL in a foreign context are the same as an include performed by a RequestDispatcher on a foreign context in the Servlet specification.
Only the 'request' environement of the importing page is available to the target resource.
The 'url' attribute must accept absolute URLs
The <c:import> action supports, at a minimum, the protocols offered in the J2SE platform for absolute URLs.

When importing resources referenced by an absolute URL, none of the current execution environment (request, session, application) is made available to the target resource, even if the absolute URL resolves to the same host and context path.

When importing an external resource using the HTTP protocol, <c:import> behaves according to the semantics of a GET request sent via the java.net.HttpURLConnection class, with setFollowRedirects set to true.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'String'.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'context' attribute specifies the name of a context when accessing a relative URL resource that belongs to a foreign context.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'String'.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The relative URL must be context-relative (i.e. must start with a "/").
The context name must also start with a "/".
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped variable for the resource's content.
The type of the exported variable is 'String'.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope in which to export 'var'.
A value of 'page' will export 'var' to the page scope.
A value of 'request' will export 'var' to the request scope.
A value of 'session' will export 'var' to the session scope.
A value of 'application' will export 'var' to the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'charEncoding' attribute specifies the character encoding of the content at the input resource.
The values supported by the 'charEncoding' attribute are the same as those supported by the constructor of the Java class java.io.InputStreamReader.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'String'.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'varReader' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped variable for the resources content.
The exported variable, as defined by the 'varReader' attribute is of type 'Reader'.
The exported variable can only be accessed within the body content of the <c:import> action.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, body content must consist of only <c:param> subtags.
If the 'varReader' attribute is specified, body content must not contain <c:param> subtags.
It is invalid to specify the 'scope' attribute if the 'varReader' attribute is defined.
The 'url' attribute is required across all syntax variations.
If the 'var' or 'varReader' attributes are not specified, the content of the imported resource is written to the current JspWriter object.
If the 'charEncoding' attribute is not specified and the response of the <c:import> request has a "Content-Type" header, then the character encoding specified is used.
If the 'charEncoding' attribute is not specified, and the response of the <c:import> request does not contain a "Content-Type" header, then the default encoding of ISO-8859-1 will be used.
If the 'scope' attibute is not specified, the variable associated with the 'var' attribute will be exported to the page scope.
If 'url' is null, empty, or invalid, a JspException is thrown.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
If an exception is caused by the action itself, it must be propagated.
If charEncoding is null or empty, it is considered missing
Error handling for internal resources:
If a RequestDispatcher cannot be found for the resource, throw a JspException with the resource path included in the message.
Otherwise, if the RequestDispatcher.include() method throws an IOException or RuntimeException, throw a JspException with the caught exception as the root cause.
Otherwise, if the RequestDispatcher.include() method throws a ServletException, look for a root cause.
If there's a root cause, throw a JspException with the root cause message included in the message and the original root cause as the JspException root cause
Otherwise, throw a JspException with the caught exception as the root cause.
Otherwise, if the resource invoked through RequestDispatcher.include() method sets a response status code other than 2xx, throw a JspException with the path and status code in the message.
Error handling for external resources:

If the URLConnection class throws an IOException or a RuntimeException, throw a JspException with the message from the original exception included in the message and the original exception as the root cause

For an HttpURLConnection, if the response status code is other than 2xx (i.e. 200-299, the range of success codes in the HTTP response codes), throw a JspException with the path and status code in the message.
If the character encoding is not specified, the following rules apply:
If URLConnection.getContentType() has a non-null result, the character set is retrieved from URLConnection.getContentType() by parsing this method's result according to RFC 2045 (section 5.1)

If this method's result does not include a character set, or if the character set causes InputStreamReader(InputStream in, String charsetName) to throw an UnsupportedEncodingException, then use ISO-8859-1
The <c:url> action builds a URL with the proper rewriting rules applied.
The 'value' attribute specifies the URL string to be processed.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'var' attribute specified the name of the exported scoped variable for the processed URL.
The type of the exported variable must be of type String.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope which to export 'var' to.
A value of 'page' will export 'var' to the page scope.
A value of 'request' will export 'var' to the request scope.
A value of 'session' will export 'var' to the session scope.
A value of 'application' will export 'var' to the application scope.
The default value of the 'scope' attribute is 'page'.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
If the 'scope' attribute is not specified, and 'var' is, 'var' will be exported to the page scope.
Only relative URLs are rewritten.
The rewriting must be performed by calling method encodeURL() of the Servlet API.
If 'var' is not specified, the result of the action is written to the current JspWriter.
If a body is present within the <c:url> tag, it must consist only of <c:param> subtags.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
If an exception is caused by the action itself, it must be propagated.
The 'context' attribute represents the name of the context when specifying a relative URL resource that belongs to a foreign context.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The URL specified must start with a leading '/'.
The context name specified must start with a leading '/'.
If the URL contains characters that should be encoded (e.g. space), it is the user's responsibility to encode them.
<c:param> is a nested action of <c:import> and <c:url> and <c:redirect>to add request parameters to the URL.
The 'name' attribute specifies the name of a query string parameter.
The result of the evaluated expression myst be of type String
The 'value' attribute specifies the value of the query string parameter.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'String'.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'encode' attribute determines whether the values of the 'name' and 'value' attributes should be URL encoded.
If the 'encode' attribute is set to 'false' no URL encoding will take place against the values of the 'name' and 'value' attributes.
If the 'encode' attribute is set to 'true', the values of the 'name' and 'value' attributes will be URL encoded.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type boolean.
If the evaluated expression is not of type boolean, an Exception is thrown.
If the result of the evaluated value is null, the default value, 'true', will be used.
If an invalid value is provided, an Exception is thrown.
If the 'encode' attribute is not specified, then the values of the 'name' and 'value' attributes will be URL encoded.
The parameter value can be specified within the body of the action.
The 'name' attribute is required across all syntax variations.
Query parameter aggregration rules work as specified for the include() method of the RequestDispatcher in the Servlet specification.
The original parameters are augmented with the new parameters, with new values taking precedence over existing values.
The scope of the new parameters is the import call; the new parameters (and values) will not apply after the import.
If 'name' is null or empty, no action is performed. It is not an error.
If value is null, it is processed as an empty value.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
The <c:redirect> action sets an HTTP redirect to the client.
The 'url' attribute specifies the URL to which the client is to be redirected.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
If body content is present within the action, it must consist of <c:param> tags.
The action uses method sendRedirect() of the Servlet API, and from doEndTag(), returns SKIP_PAGE
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
If an exception is caused by the action itself, it must be propagated.
The 'context' attribute specifies the name of the context when redirecting to a relative URL resource that belongs to a foreign context.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The URL specified must start with a leading '/'.
The context name specified must start with a leading '/'.
An i18n action determines its localization context as follows:
If attribute 'bundle' is specified in <fmt:message>, the i18n localization context associated with it is used for localization.

If <fmt:message> actions that do not contain the 'bundle' attribute are nested inside a <fmt:bundle> action, the i18n localization context of the enclosing <fmt:bundle> action is used for localization.
Otherwise, the i18n localization context whose resource bundle is to be used for localization is specified via the jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.localizationContext configuration setting.
If the configuration setting is of type LocalizationContext its resource bundle component is used for localization.

Otherwise, the configuration setting is of type String, and the action establishes its own i18n localization context whose resource bundle component is determined according to the resource bundle determination algorithm in Section 8.3, using the configuration setting as the resource bundle basename.
The method for setting the preferred locales is characterized as either application-based or browser-based.
Application-based locale setting has priority over browser-based locale setting.
In application-based mode, the locale is set via the jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.locale configuration setting

In the browser-based locale setting, the client determines via its browser settings which locale(s) should be used by the web application. The action retrieves the client's locale preferences by calling ServletRequest.getLocales() on the incoming request
Given a basename and an ordered set of preferred locales, the resource bundle for an I18N localization context is determined according to a specified algorithm.
Resource bundles are searched in the following order: - basename + _ + language + _ + country + _ + variant - basename + _ + language + _ + country - basename + _ + language - basename
The resource bundle determination algorithm is comprised of two steps.
Find a match within the ordered set of preferred locales.
A resource bundle look up is performed for each one of the preferred locales (processed in the order returned by ServletRequest.getLocales()) until a match is found.

If the resource lookup fails for the preferred locales, a resource bundle lookup is performed for the fallback locale specified in the jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.fallbackLocale scoped attribute or context configuration parameter.
If no match is found is found following the specified steps, an attempt is made to load the root resource bundle with the given basename.
If such a resource bundle exists, it is used as the resource bundle of an i18n localization context that does not have any locale.

Otherwise, the established i18n localization context contains neither a resource bundle nor a locale. It is then up to the i18n action relying on this i18n localization context for the localization of its data to take a proper corrective action.
The alogrithm must give a higher priority to a 'language' match over an 'exact' match that would have occurred further down the list of preferred locales.
The algorithm must never consider the default locale associated with the Java runtime of the container as this would result in non-portable behavior.
The behavior is implementation-specific if the set of available resource bundles changes during the execution of the page.
Implementations may cache whatever information they deem necessary to improve performance of the algorithm presented in this section.

Any I18N action that establishes a localization context is responsible for setting the response's locale of its page by calling ServletResponse.setLocale() with the locale of the localization context.

After an action has called ServletResponse.setLocale(), it must call ServletResponse.getCharacterEncoding() and store the result in the 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.request.charset' session attribute.
<fmt:setLocale> stores the specified locale in the jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.locale configuration variable.

The 'value' attribute specifies a printable representation of a locale, which must contain a two-letter (lower case) language code (as defined by ISO-639), and may contain a two-letter (upper-case) country code (as defined by ISO-3166). Language and country codes must be separated by a hyphen ('-') or an underscore ('_').
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String or java.util.Locale.
The locale specified by the attribute 'value' will be assigned to the scoped attribute 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.locale'.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String or java.util.Locale, an Exception is thrown.
The 'variant' attribute specifies a Vendor- or browser-specified variant as defined in the javdocs of java.util.Locale.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope of the locale.
A value of 'page' will set the attribute 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.locale' to the page scope.
A value of 'request' will set attribute 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.locale' to the request scope.
A value of 'session' will set attribute 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.locale' to the session scope.
A value of 'application' will set attribute 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.locale' to the page application.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
If the 'scope' attribute is not specified, the 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.ftm.locale' attribute will be set to the page scope.
The 'value' attribute is required.
If the 'value' attribute is null or empty, the runtime default locale is used.
If the 'value' attribute is of type java.util.Locale, 'variant' is ignored.
It is invalid for the action to have a body.
The <fmt:bundle> action creates an i18n localization context to be used by its body content.
The 'basename' attribute specifies the resource bundle base name.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The specific resource bundle that is loaded is determined according to the algorithm presented in Section 8.3.2.
The 'prefix' attribute specifies the prefix to be prepended to any message keys that are looked up in the resource bundle that was loaded by this action.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the scoped variable which stores the resource bundle.
The type of the variable must be java.util.ResourceBundle.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute defines the scope of the 'var' attribute.
Setting the 'scope' attribute value to 'page' will export 'var' to the page scope.
Setting the 'scope' attribute value to 'request' will export 'var' to the request scope.
Setting the 'scope' attribute value to 'session' will export 'var' to the session scope.
Setting the 'scope' attribute value to 'application' will export 'application' to the page scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
If the 'scope' attribute is not specified, the default scope of the 'var' attribute must be 'page'.
The 'basename' attribute is required.
The JSP container processes the body content and then writes it to the current JspWriter object (the action ignores the body).

A <fmt:bundle> action with no body content and with no 'var' attribute specified will set or override the 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.basename' attribute in the scope given by the scope attribute, thereby making its base name the (new) default for that scope.
If basename is null or empty, or a resource bundle cannot be found, the null resource bundle is stored in the i18n localization context
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
The scope of the i18n localization context is limited to the action's body content.
The <fmt:setBundle> action creates an i18n localization context and stores it in the scoped variable or the jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.localizationContext configuration variable.
The 'basename' attribute specifies the resource bundle base name.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The basename attribute is required.
The specific resource bundle that is loaded is determined according to the algorithm presented in Section 8.3.2.
If basename is null or empty, or a resource bundle cannot be found, the null resource bundle is stored in the i18n localization context.
The 'var' attribute specifies the exported scoped variable which stores the i18n localization context of type jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.LocalizationContext.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.

If var is not specified, the i18n localization context is stored in the jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.localizationContext configuration variable, thereby making it the new default i18n localization context in the given scope.
The 'scope' attribute determines the scope of the var attribute or the localization context configuration variable.
Setting the 'scope' attribute value to 'page' will export 'var' to the page scope.
Setting the 'scope' attribute value to 'request'' will export 'var' to the request scope.
Setting the 'scope' attribute value to 'session' will export 'var' to the session scope.
Setting the 'scope' attribute value to 'application' will export 'var' to the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
The default value of the 'scope' attribute is 'page.'
The body content must be empty.
The <fmt:message> action looks up a localized message in a resource bundle.
The 'key' attribute specifies the message key to be looked up.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'bundle' attribute specifies the resource bundle in which to look up the message key.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type ResourceBundle
If the evaluated expression is not of type ResourceBundle, an Exception is thrown.
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped attribute which stores the localized message.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope of 'var'.
A value of 'page' will export 'var' to the page scope.
A value of 'request' will export 'var' to the request scope.
A value of 'session' will export 'var' to the session scope.
A value of 'application' will export 'var' to the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
The default value of the 'scope' attribute is 'page'.
The action must accept a message key within the tag's body content
If this action is nested inside a <fmt:bundle> action, and the parent <fmt:bundle> action contains a prefix attribute, the specified prefix is prepended to the message key.
If the given key is not found in the resource bundle, or a resource bundle with the given base name does not exist, two actions must occur:
A message is logged to the servlet context.
An error message of the form "???<key>???" (where <key> is the name of the undefined message key) is output to the current JspWriter object.

If the message corresponding to the given key is compound (contains one or more variables), and the action's body contains one or more <fmt:param> subtags (one for each parameter), then parametric replacement of the parameters will take place in the order that the <fmt:param> subtags were provided.
If the message is compound and no <fmt:param> subtags are specified, it is left unmodified.
If 'scope' is specified, 'var' must also be specified.
If 'key' is null or empty, the message is processed as if undefined; i.e, an error message of the form "??????" is written.
If 'scope' is not specified, and 'var' is, then 'var' will be exported to the page scope.
If 'key' is null or empty, the message is processed as if undefined; that is, an error message of the form "??????" is produced.
If the i18n localization context that this action determines does not have any resource bundle, an error message of the form ???<key>??? is produced

In the presence of one or more <fmt:param> subtags, the message is supplied to the java.text.MessageFormat method applyPattern(), and the values of the <fmt:param> tags are collected in an Object[] and supplied to the java.text.MessageFormat method format().
The locale of the java.text.MessageFormat is set to the appropriate localization context locale before applyPattern() is called.

If the localization context does not have any locale, the locale of the java.text.MessageFormat is set to the locale returned by the formatting locale lookup algorithm of Section 9.3, except that the available formatting locales are given as the intersection of the number- and date- formatting locales.
If this algorithm does not yield any locale, the locale of the java.text.MessageFormat is set to the runtime's default locale.
The <fmt:param> action supplies a single parameter for parametric replacement to a containing <fmt:message> action.
The 'value' attribute specifies the argument used for parametric replacement.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'Object'.
If the evaluated expression is not of type Object, an Exception is thrown.
The value of the parameter can be specified as body content of the action.
The <fmt:param> action must be nested in a <fmt:message> action.
Parametric replacement must take place in order of the <fmt:param> tags.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
The <fmt:requestEncoding> action sets the request's character encoding.
The 'value' attribute specifies the name of the character encoding to be applied when decoding request parameters.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
It is invalid for this action to have a body.
This action calls the setCharacterEncoding() method on the servlet request with the character encoding name specified in the 'value' attribute.
The following events will occur if the 'value' attribute is not set:
The action will check if there is a charset defined in the request Content-Type header. If found, the charset defined will be used.
If no Content-Type header is found, the action will use the encoding defined by the 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.request.charset' scoped attribute.
If the 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.request.charset' scoped attribute is not found, the default character encoding, ISO-8859-1, is used.
The jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.locale configuration setting disables browser-based locales.
The specific locale that a formatting action uses to localize its data is determined as follws:
If a formatting action is nested inside a <fmt:bundle> action, the locale of the enclosing resource bundle is used as the formatting locale.

Otherwise, if a default localization context for I18N actions is specified via the 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.localizationContext' configuration setting, and its value is of type LocalizationContext, then its locale is used as the formatting locale.

Otherwise, if a default localization context for I18N actions is specified via the 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.localizationContext' configuration setting, and its value is of type String, the formatting action establishes its own i18n localization context and uses its locale as the formatting locale
If the locale cannot be determined according to the three preceding steps, the formatting action itself establishes a localization context according to an alogrithm based on the preferred locales.
The locales available for actions <fmt:formatNumber> and <fmt:parseNumber> are determined by a call to java.text.NumberFormat.getAvailableLocales().
The locales available for actions <fmt:formatDate> and <fmt:parseDate> are determined by a call to java.text.DateFormat.getAvailableLocales().
A match of the specified locale against an available locale is therefore attempted in the following order:
language, country, and variant are the same.
language and country are the same.
language is the same and the available local does not have a country.
The locale lookup algorithm is comprised of two steps and will stop processing as soon as a locale has been selected for the localization context.

assertion.id: JSTL:SPEC:A local lookup is performed for each one of the preferred locales until a match is found. The first match found becomes the selected locale for the localization context.

assertion.description: The locales will be processed by the alogrithm in the order they were returned by a call to ServletRequest.getLocales().

A locale lookup is performed for the fallback locale specified in the 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.fallbackLocale' scoped attribute or context configuration parameter. If a match exists, it becomes the selected locale for the localization context.
If no match is found, the default JVM locale is used.
The 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.timeZone' scoped attribute or context configuration parameter specifies the time zone in which to format or parse time information.
If the jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.timeZone scoped attribute or context configuration parameter does not exist, the JSP container's time zone is used.
The <fmt:timeZone> action specifies the time zone in which time information is to be formatted or parsed.
The 'value' attribute specifies the time zone.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String or java.util.TimeZone.
A string value is interpreted as a time zone ID.
The time zone can be specified as one of the time zone IDs supported by the Java platform.
The time zone can be specified as a custom format (such as "GMT-8:00").
If the evaluated expression is not of type String or type java.util.Timezone, an Exception is thrown.
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped attribute.
The type of the exported variable must be of type java.util.TimeZone.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute sets the scope for attributes.
A value of 'page' sets the attribute to the page scope.
A value of 'request' sets the attribute to the request scope.
A value of 'session' sets the attribute to the session scope.
A value of 'application' sets the attribute to the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
If neither 'var' nor 'scope' is specified, then the attribute 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.timeZone' is set to the value specified and exported to the page scope.
If 'scope'' is specified, and 'var' is not, the attribute 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.timeZone' is set to the value specified by 'value' to the specified scope.
If 'var' is specified, and 'scope' is not, then the attribute specified by var will be exported to the page scope.
If 'value' is null or empty, the GMT timezone is used.
The JSP container processes the body content and then writes it to the current JspWriter. The action ignores the body content.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
<fmt:setTimeZone> stores the specified time zone in a scoped variable or the time zone configuration variable.
The 'value' attribute specifies the time zone.
The 'value' attribute is required.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String or java.util.TimeZone.
A string value is interpreted as a time zone ID.
The time zone can be specified as one of the time zone IDs supported by the Java platform.
The time zone can be specified as a custom format (such as "GMT-8:00").
If the evaluated expression is not of type String or type java.util.Timezone, an Exception is thrown.
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped attribute.
The type of the exported variable must be of type java.util.TimeZone.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute sets the scope for attributes.
A value of 'page' sets the attribute to the page scope.
A value of 'request' sets the attribute to the request scope.
A value of 'session' sets the attribute to the session scope.
A value of 'application' sets the attribute to the application scope.
The default value of the attribute is 'page.'
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
If var is not specified, the time zone is stored in the jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.timeZone configuration variable, thereby making it the new default time zone in the given scope.
The body content must be empty.
If the time zone is given as a string, it is parsed using java.util.TimeZone.getTimeZone().
If 'value' is null or empty, the GMT timezone is used.
The <fmt:formatNumber> action formats a numeric value in a local-sensitive or customized manner as a number, currency, or percentage.
The 'value' attribute specifies the numeric value to be formatted.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String or Number.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String or Number, an Exception is thrown.
The 'type' attribute specifies how the value should be formatted.
A value of 'number' will format the value as a number.
A value of 'currency' will format the value as a currency.
A value of 'percentage' will format the value as a percentage.
If the value evaluates to null, the default value, 'number', will be used.
An invalid value will result in an Exception being thrown.
The 'pattern' attribute specifies a custom formatting pattern (applied only when formatting numbers).
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'currencyCode' attribute specifies the ISO 4217 current code (applied only when formatting currencies).
If 'currencyCode' is specified, and type is not 'currency', then 'currencyCode' is ignored.
The result of the evaluated expression my be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
the 'currencySymbol' attribute specifies the current symbol (applied only when formatting currencies).
If 'currencySymbol' is specified, and 'type' is not 'currency', then 'currencySymbol' is ignored.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
the 'groupingUsed' attribute specifies whether the formatted output will contain any grouping separators.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type boolean.
If the evaluated expression is not of type boolean, an Exception is thrown.
If the value evaluates to null, the default value, 'true', will be used.
An invalid value will result in an Exception being thrown.
The 'maxIntegerDigits' attribute specifies the maximum number of digits in the integer portion of the formatted output.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type int.
If the evaluated expression is not of type int, an Exception is thrown.
The 'minIntegerDigits' attribute specifies the minimum number of digits in the integer portion of the formatted output.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type int.
If the evaluated expression is not of type int, an Exception is thrown.
The 'maxFractionDigits' attribute specifies the maximum number of digits in the fractional portion of the formatted output.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type int.
If the evaluated expression is not of type int, an Exception is thrown.
The 'minFractionDigits' attribute specifies the minimum number of digits in the fractional portion of the formatted output.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type int.
If the evaluated expression is not of type int, an Exception is thrown.
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped attribute which stores the formatted value.
The type of the exported attribute must be String.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope of 'var'.
A value of 'page' will export 'var' to the page scope.
A value of 'request' will export 'var' to the request scope.
A value of 'session' will export 'var' to the session scope.
A value of 'application' will export 'var' to the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
If the 'type' attribute is not specified, 'number' will be used.
If 'var' is specified, but 'scope' is not, 'var' will be exported to the page scope.
If 'scope' is specified, 'var' must also be specified.
The value of the 'currencyCode' attribute must be a valid ISO 4217 currency code.
If 'value' is null or empty, nothing is written to the current JspWriter object and the scoped variable is removed if it is specified.
The value to be formatted can be specified as body content of the action.

If the numeric value to be formatted is given as a string literal, it is parsed into an instance of java.lang.Number. If the string does not contain any decimal point, it is parsed using java.lang.Long.valueOf(), or java.lang.Double.valueOf() otherwise.
A 'jakarta.servlet.jsp.JspException' is thrown if the number to be formatted is given as a string and cannot be parsed as a number.
The formatted result is written to the current JspWritter object if 'var' is not specified.
The presence of the 'pattern' attribute will override the predefined formatting pattern of the page's locale.
The given pattern string must follow the pattern syntax specified in the documentation for the java.text.DecimalFormat class.
The presence of the 'currencySymbol' attribute will override the predefined currency symbol of the page's locale.
The presence of the 'currencyCode' attribute will override the predefined currency code of the page's locale.
If the container's runtime is J2SE 1.4 or greater:
If both 'currencyCode' and 'currencySymbol' are present, 'currencyCode' takes precedence over 'currencySymbol'.
If the container's runtime is less than J2SE 1.4:
If both 'currencyCode' and 'currencySymbol' are present, 'currencySymbol' takes precedence over 'currencyCode'.
If only 'currencyCode' is given, it is used as a currency symbol.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.

If a formatting pattern is not specified via the pattern attribute, it is looked up in a locale-dependent fashion determined via a combination of the formatting locale, which is determined according to Section 9.2, and the type attribute.
Depending on the value of the type attribute, the given numeric value is formatted as a number, currency, or percentage

The locale's default formatting pattern for numbers, currencies, or percentages is determined by calling the java.text.NumberFormat method getNumberInstance, getCurrencyInstance, or getPercentInstance, respectively, with the formatting locale.
Symbols in a formatting pattern are determined by the locale.
If the numeric value is given as a string literal, it is first parsed into a java.lang.Number.
If the numeric value is given as a string literal, it is first parsed into a java.lang.Number.
If the string does not contain any decimal point, it is parsed using java.lang.Long.valueOf().
Otherwise, it is parsed using java.lang.Double.valueOf().
The formatted result is output to the current JspWriter object, unless the var attribute is given, in which case it is stored in the named scoped variable.
The pattern attribute takes precedence over type.
The <fmt:parseNumber> action parses the string representation of numbers, currencies, and percentages that were formatted in a locale-sensitive or customized.
The 'value' attribute specifies the string to be parsed.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'type' attribute specifies how 'value' should be parsed.
A value of 'number' will format value as a number.
A value of 'currency' will format value as a currency.
A value of 'percentage' will format the value as a percentage.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
If the value evaluates to null, the default value, 'number', will be used.
An invalid value will result in an Exception being thrown.
The 'pattern' attribute specifies a custom formatting pattern which determines how the string in the 'value' attribute is to be parsed.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.

The 'parseLocale' attribute specifies the locale whose default formatting pattern (for numbers, currencies, or percentages) is to be used during the parse operation, or to which the pattern specified via the 'pattern' attribute (if present) is applied.

The 'isolation' attribute specifies the transaciton isolation level.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
A value of 'read_committed' sets the transaction isolation level to TRANSACTION_READ_COMMITTED.
A value of 'read_uncommitted' sets the transaction isolation level to TRANSACTION_READ_UNCOMMITTED.
A value of 'repeatable_read' sets the transaction isolation level to TRANSACTION_REPEATABLE_READ.
A value of 'serializable' sets the transaction isolation level to TRANSACTION_SERIALIZABLE.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
If the isolation level is not specified, it is the isolation level the DataSource has been configured with.
If the value evaluates to null, the default value, 'default', will be used.
An invalid value will result in an Exception being thrown.
Any nested <sql:query> and <sql:update> actions must not specify a 'dataSource' attribute.
If 'dataSource' is null, a JspException is thrown.
The tag handler of the <sql:transaction> action must perform the following steps in it's lifecycle methods:
doStartTag():
Determine the transaction isolation level of the DBMS (using the Connection method getTransactionIsolation()).
If transactions are not supported, an exception is raised causing the transaction to fail.
For any other transaction isolation level, the auto-commit mode is disabled by calling setAutoCommit(false) on the connection.
If the 'isolation' attribute is specified, the current transaction isolation level is save and set to the specified level (using the Connection method setTransactionIsolation()).
doEndTag():
Calls the cConnection method commit().
doCatch():
Calls the Connection method rollback().
doFinally():
If a transaction isolation level has been saved, it is restored using the Connection meghod setTransactionIsolation().
Enables auto-commit mode by calling setAutoCommit(true) on the Connection.
Closes the connection.
Any exception occurring during the execution of this action must be caught and rethrown after the transaction has been rolled back.

The <sql:param> action is used as a subtag of SQLExecutionTag actions such as <sql:query> and <sql:update> to set the values of parameter markers ('?') in a SQL statement.

If 'value' is null, the parameter is set to SQL NULL.

The <sql:param> action substitutes the given parameter value for a parameter marker(?) in the SQL statement of its enclosing SQLExecutionTag action.
The specified parameters are substituted in the order in which they are specified.
