<sql:dateParam> Sets the values of parameter markers (?) in a SQL statement for values of type java.util.Date. Subtag of SQLExecutionTag actions, such as <sql:query> and <sql:update>.
The 'value' attribute represents a parameter value for DATE, TIME, or TIMESTAMP column in a database table.
The 'value' attribute is required.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type java.util.Date.
If the evaluated expression is not of type java.util.Date, an Exception is thrown.
If value is null, the parameter is set to the SQL value NULL
The 'type' attribute represents one of "date", "time" or "timestamp".
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The body content must be empty.
The <sql:dateParam> tags must be nested inside an action whose tag handler is an instance of SQLExecutionTag.
<sql:dateParam> converts the provided java.util.Date instance to one of java.sql.Date, java.sql.Time or java.sql.Timestamp as defined by the type attribute as follows:

If the java.util.Date object provided by the value attribute is an instance of java.sql.Time, java.sql.Date, or java.sql.Timestamp, and the type attribute matches this object's type, then it is passed as is to the database.
Otherwise, the object is converted to the appropriate type by calling that type's constructor with a parameter of date.getTime(), where date is the value of the value attribute.
The <sql:dateParam> action substitutes the given parameter value for a parameter marker(?) in the SQL statement of its enclosing SQLExecutionTag action.
Parameters are substituted in the order in which they are specified.
The <sql:dateParam> action locates its nearest ancestor that is an instance of SQLExecutionTag and calls its addSQLParameter() method, supplying it with the given parameter value.
The XPath engine must support the following scopes:
$foo -> pageContext.findAttribute("foo")
$pageScope:foo -> pageContext.getAttribute("foo", PageContext.PAGE_SCOPE)
$requestScope:foo -> pageContext.getAttribute("foo", PageContext.REQUEST_SCOPE)
$sessionScope:foo -> pageContext.getAttribute("foo", PageContext.SESSION_SCOPE)
$applicationScope:foo -> pageContext.getAttribute("foo", PageContext.APPLICATION_SCOPE)
$param:foo -> request.getParameter("foo")
$header:foo -> request.getHeader("foo")
$cookie:foo -> maps the cookies value for name foo.
$initParam:foo -> application.getInitParameter("foo")
The following Java to XPath type mappings must be supported:
Java: java.lang.Boolean -> XPath: boolean
Java: java.lang.Number -> XPath: number
Java: java.lang.String -> XPath: string
Object exported by <x:parse> -> node-set
XPath variable references that address objects of other types result in implementation specified behavior.
The following XPath to Java type mappings must be supported:
XPath: boolean -> Java: java.lang.Boolean
XPath: number (a floaing point number) -> Java: java.lang.Number
XPath: string (a sequence of UCS characters) -> Java: java.lang.String
XPath node-set -> Java: Type usable by JSTL XML-manipulation tags in the same JSTL Implementation. The specified Java type representing the node-sets may thus vary by implementation.
The <x:parse> action parses an XML document.
The 'systemIDl' attribute specifies the URL of the source XML document to be parsed.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'xml' attribute specifies the source XML document to be parsed.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String or Reader
If the evaluated expression is not of type String or Reader, an Exception is thrown.
The 'doc' attribute specifies the source XML document to be parsed.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String or Reader
If the evaluated expression is not of type String or Reader, an Exception is thrown.
The 'filter' attribute specifies the filter to be applied to the source document.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'org.xml.sax.XMLFilter'
If the evaluated expression is not of type org.xml.sax.XMLFilter, an Exception is thrown.
If filter is null, filtering is not performed
The 'var' attribute specifies the named of the exported scoped attribute for the parsed XML document.
The type of the exported scoped attribute is implementation specified.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope in which to export 'var'.
A value of 'page' will export 'var' to the page scope.
A value of 'request' will export 'var' to the request scope.
A value of 'session' will export 'var' to the session scope.
A value of 'application' will export 'var' to the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'varDom' attribute specifies the exported scoped attribute for the parsed XML document.
The exported scoped attribute must be of type org.w3c.dom.Document.
The 'scopeDom' attribute specifies the scope in which to export 'varDom'.
A value of 'page' will export 'varDom' to the page scope.
A value of 'request' will export 'varDom' to the request scope.
A value of 'session' will export 'varDom' to the session scope.
A value of 'application' will export 'varDom' to the application scope.
If the scopeDom attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
It is invalid to specify 'xmlUrl' if the action has body-content.
It is invalid to specify 'xmlTest' if the action has body-content.
One and only one of var and varDom must be specified
If 'scope' is specified, 'var' must also be specified.
If 'scopeDom' is specified, 'varDom' must also be specified.
If 'xmlUrl' is null or empty, a JspException is thrown.
The document to be parsed can be specified as body content of the action.
The 'var' or 'varDom' attribute is required across all syntax variations.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
If an exception is caused by the action, it must be propagated.
If the source XML document is null or empty, a JspException is thrown.
The <x:out> action evaluates an XPath expression and outputs the result of the evaluation to the current JspWriter object.
The 'select' attribute specifies the XPath expression to be evaluated.
The 'escapeXml' attribute determines wheth characters <,>,&,'," in the result string should be converted to their corresponding character entity codes.
'<' is converted to \<
'>' is converted to \>
'&' is converted to \&
Single quote (') is converted to &#039.
Double quote (") is converted to &#034.
If the value evaluates to null, the default value, 'true', will be used.
An invalid value will result in an Exception being thrown.
If 'escaleXml' is not specified, then escaping will be performed.
It is illegal for the <x:out> action to have body content.
A JspException is thrown if the expression language reports a failure to complete the evaluation of the expression.
The 'select' attribute is required.
If an exception is caused by the action itself, it must be propagated.
The <x:set> actions evaluates an XPath expression and sets the result into a scoped variable.
The 'select' attribute specifies the XPath expression to be evaluated.
The 'var' attribute specifies the named of the exported scoped attribute which holds the result of the evaluated XPath expression.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope in which to export 'var'.
A value of 'page' exports 'var' to the page scope.
A value of 'request' exports 'var' to the request scope.
A value of 'session' exports 'var' to the session scope.
A value of 'application' exports 'var' to the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
If 'scope' is not specified, 'var' will be exported to the page scope.
The 'var' attribute is required across all syntax variations.
The value of the scoped variable can also be specified as body content.
The 'var' attribute is required across all syntax variations.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
The body content must be empty.
The <x:if> action evaluates the XPath expression and renders its body content if the expression evaluates to true.
The 'select' attribute specifies the test condition determines whether the body content should be processed.
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped attribute for the resulting value of the test condition.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute specifieds the scope in which to export 'var'
A value of 'page' will export 'var' to the page scope.
A value of 'reqeust' will export 'var' to the request scope.
A value of 'session' will export 'var' to the session scope.
A value of 'application' will export 'var' to the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
If 'scope' is specified, 'var' must also be specified.
If the test condition evaluates to true, the JSP container processes the body content and then writes it to the current JspWriter.
The 'select' attribute is required.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
The <x:choose> action provides the context for mutually exclusive conditional execution.
The body content of must consist of only:
White space may appear anywhere around teh <x:when> and <x:otherwise> subtags.
1 to N <x:when> actions which must all appear before <x:otherwise>
0 or 1 <x:otherwise> action which must be the last nested action in <x:choose>
The body content is processed by the JSP container and written to the current JspWriter.
The action processes the body of the first <x:when> action whose test condition evaluates to true.
If none of the test conditions of nested <x:when> actions evaluates to true, then the body of the <x:otherwise> action is processed, if present.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
The <x:when> action represents an alternative within an <x:choose> action.
The 'select' attribute specifies the test condition that determines whether the body content should be processed.
<x:when> must have <x:choose> as an immediate parent.
<x:when> must appear before an <x:otherwise> action that has the same parent.
If the test condition of the action evaluates to true, the JSP container processes the body content and then writes it to the current JspWriter.
The 'select' attribute is required.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
The <x:otherwise> action is used optionally as the last alternative within a <x:choose> action.
The <x:otherwise> action must have <x:choose> as an immediate parent.
The <x:otherwise> action must be the last nested action within <x:choose>

If none of the nested <x:when> test conditions evaluates to true, then the body content of the <x:otherwise> action is evaluated by the JSP container, and the result is written to the current JspWriter.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
The <x:forEach> action evaluates the given XPath expression and repeats its nested body content over the result, setting the context node to each element in the iteration.
The 'select' attribute specifies the XPath expression to be evaluated.
The 'var' attribute specified the named of the exported scoped attribute for the current item of the iteration.
The type of the exported attribute depends on the object of the underlying collection.
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
If 'select' is emtpy, a JspException is thrown.
As long as there are items to iterate over, the body content is processed by the JSP container and written to the current JspWriter.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
The 'varStatus' attribute specifies the name of the scoped variable for the status of the iteration
The exported Object associated with the value of the 'varStatus' attribute is of type jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.core.LoopTagStatus.
The 'begin' attribute specifies a starting index value.
If the 'items' attribute is specified, the 'begin' attribute dictates that the iteration begins at the item located at the specified index.
The first item of the collection has index 0.
If the 'items' attribute is not specified, the 'begin' attribute dictates that iteration begins with the index set at the value specified.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'int'.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type 'int'
The 'end' attribute specifies an ending index value.
If the 'items' attribute is specified, the 'ends' attribute dictates that the Iteration ends at the item located at the specified index.
If the 'items' attribute is not specified, the 'end' attribute dictates that iteration ends when the index reaches the value specified.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'int'.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type int, an Exception is thrown.
The 'step' attribute specifies that iteration will only process every 'step' items of the collections, starting with the first.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'int'.
If the result of the evaluated expression is not of type int, an Exception is thrown.
If 'begin' is specified, the value must be >= 0.
If 'end' is specified, the value must be >= 'begin'
If 'step' is specified, step must be >= 1
If end is specified and it is less than begin, the loop is simply not executed.
The <x:transform> action applies a transformation to an XML document given a specified XSLT stylesheet or a transformer object.
The 'xmlSystemID' attribute specifies the URL of the source XML document to be transformed.
The result of the evaluated expression must be String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'docSystemID' attribute specifies the URL of the source XML document to be transformed.
The result of the evaluated expression must be String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'xml' attribute specifies the source XML document to be transformed.
The type of the evaluated expression can be:
String
Reader
javax.xml.transform.Source
An object exported by <x:parse> or <x:set>
org.w3c.dom.Document
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, Reader, javax.xml.transform.Source, org.w3c.dom.Document, or an Object exported by <x:parse> or <x:set>, an Exception is thrown.
The 'doc' attribute specifies the source XML document to be transformed.
The type of the evaluated expression can be:
String
Reader
javax.xml.transform.Source
An object exported by <x:parse> or <x:set>
org.w3c.dom.Document
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, Reader, javax.xml.transform.Source, org.w3c.dom.Document, or an Object exported by <x:parse> or <x:set>, an Exception is thrown.
The 'xsltSystemID' attribute specifies the URL of the transformation stylesheet.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'xslt' attribute specifies the transformation stylesheet.
The type of the evaluated expression can be:
String
Reader
javax.xml.transform.Source
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, Reader, or javax.xml.transform.Source, an Exception is thrown.
The 'var' attribute specifies the name of the exported scoped attribute to hold the result of the transformation.
The type of the exported attribute must be 'org.w3c.dom.Document'
If the 'var' attribute is specified, but empty, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope in which to export 'var'.
A value of 'page' will export 'var' to the page scope.
A value of 'request' will export 'var' to the request scope.
A value of 'session' will export 'var' to the session scope.
A value of 'application' will export 'var' to the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value, a translation time validation error will occur.
The 'result' attribute specifies how the tranformation result should be processed.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type 'javax.xml.transform.Result'.
If the evaluated expression is not of type javax.xml.transform.Result, an Exception is thrown.
If 'scope' is specified, 'var' must be specified also.
If 'doc' or 'xslt' is null or empty, a JspException is thrown.
If 'var' or 'result' is not specified, the result of the transformation is written to the current JspWriter.
One and only one attribute, either 'xmlUrl' or 'xmlText', must be present in the action, if the action has no body content.
One and only one attribute, either 'xsltUrl' or 'xsltText', must be present in the action, across all syntax variations.
The XML document to be parsed can be specified as body content of the action.
<x:param> subtags can be nested after the XML content within the actions body.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
If an exception is caused by the action itself, it must be propagated.
The <x:param> nested action of <x:transform> is used to set transformation parameters.
The 'name' attribute specifies the name of the transformation parameter.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The 'value' attribute specifies the value of the parameter.
The result of the evaluated expression must be of type String.
If the evaluated expression is not of type String, an Exception is thrown.
The value of the parameter can be specified via the actions body content.
If an exception is caused by the body content, it must be propagated.
The PermittedTaglibsTLV class is used to allow a TLD to restrict what taglibs (in addition to itself) may be imported on a page where it's used.
The ScriptFreeTLV class is used for enforcing restrictions against the use of JSP scripting elements.
The allowDeclarations initialization parameter, if true, indicates that declaration elements are not prohibited.
The allowScriptlets initialization parameter, if true, indicates that scriptlets elements are not prohibited.
The allowExpressions initialization parameter, if true, indicates that top-level expression elements (i.e., expressions not associated with request-time attribute values) are not prohibited.
The allowRTExpressions initialization parameter, if true, indicates that expression elements associated with request-time attribute values are not prohibited.
The default value for all for initialization parameters is false, indicating all forms of scripting elements are to be prohibited.
The fn:contains function tests if a string contains the specified substring.
fn:contains has two arguments, string and substring.
The string argument is of type String.
If string is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The substring argument is of type String.
If substring is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The result is of type Boolean.
The result is true if the character sequence represented by the substring argument exists in the character sequence represented by the string argument, false otherwise.
If substring is empty, this matches the beginning of the string and the value returned is true.
The fn:containsIgnoreCase function tests if a string contains the specified substring.
fn:containsIgnoreCase has two arguments, string and substring.
The string argument is of type String.
If string is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The substring argument is of type String.
If substring is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The result is of type Boolean.
The result is true if the character sequence represented by the substring argument exists in the character sequence represented by the string argument ignoring case differences, false otherwise.
If substring is empty, this matches the beginning of the string and the value returned is true.
fn:endsWith tests if a string ends with the specified suffix.
fn:endsWith has two arguments, string and suffix.
The string argument is of type String.
If string is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The suffix argument is of type String.
If suffix is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The result is of type Boolean.
The result is true if the character sequence represented by the suffix argument is a suffix of the character sequence represented by the string argument, false otherwise.
If suffix is empty, this matches the end of the string and the value returned is true.
fn:escapeXml escapes characters that could be interpreted as XML markup.
fn:escapeXml has a single argument, string, of type String
The result is a converted string. The conversions are the same as the ones applied by <c:out> when attribute escapeXml is set to true.
If string is null, it is processed as an empty string.
If string is an empty string, an empty string is returned.
fn:indexOf returns the index within a string of the first occurrence of a specified substring.
fn:indexOf has two arguments
The string argument is of type String.
If string is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The substring argument is of type String.
If substring is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The result is an integer
If the substring argument is a substring of the input string, the result is the index of the first character of the first such substring.
If the substring argument does not occur as a substring, -1 is returned.
If substring is empty, this matches the beginning of the string and the value returned is 0.
fn:join joins all elements of an array into a string.
fn:join has two arguments
The array argument is an array of Strings to be joined
The separator argument is a String to separate each element of the array in the resulting string.
If separator is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The result is a String of all array elements joined into one string.
If the array argument is null, an empty string is returned.
If the separator argument is an empty string, then the elements are joined together without any separator.
fn:length Returns the number of items in a collection, or the number of characters in a string.
fn:length has a single argument, input, which may be any of the types supported for the items attribute in the <c:forEach> action, or String.
The result is an int representing the length of the collection or the string.
If input is null, it is treated as an empty collection and the value returned is 0.
If input is an empty string, the value returned is 0.
fn:replace returns a string resulting from replacing in an input string all occurrences of a "before" substring into an "after" substring.
fn:replace has three arguments.
The inputString argument is of type String
If inputString is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The beforeSubstring argument is of type String
If beforeSubstring is null, it is processed as an empty string
The afterSubstring argument is of type String
If afterSubstring is null, it is processed as an empty string
The result is the string that results from replacing all occurrences of beforeSubstring by afterSubstring.
If inputstring is an empty string, an empty string is returned.
If beforeSubstring is an empty string, the input string is returned.
If afterSubstring is an empty string, all occurrences of beforeSubstring are removed from inputString
fn:split splits a string into an array of substrings.
fn:split has two arguments
The string argument is of type String.
If string is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The delimiters argument is of type String.
If delimiters is null, it is processed as an empty string
The result is an array of Strings
If both arguments are non-empty, the input string is broken into tokens according to the semantics of the Java class java.util.StringTokenizer
If the input string is empty, the array returned contains one element consisting of an empty string.
If delimiters is an empty string, the array returned contains one element consisting of the input string
Delimiter characters themselves are not treated as tokens, and are not included in any token.
fn:startsWith tests if a string starts with the specified prefix.
fn:startsWith has two arguments, string and prefix.
The string argument is of type String.
If string is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The prefix argument is of type String.
If prefix is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The result is of type Boolean.
The result is true if the character sequence represented by the prefix argument is a prefix of the character sequence represented by the string argument, false otherwise.
If prefix is empty, this matches the beginning of the string and the value returned is true.
fn:substring returns a subset of a string.
fn:substring has three arguments.
The argument string is of type String.
If string is null, it is processed as an empty string
The beginIndex argument is an int.
If beginIndex is less than 0, its value is adjusted to be 0.
The endIndex argument is an int.
If endIndex is less than 0 or greater than the length of the input string, its value is adjusted to be the length of the input string.
The result is of type String.

Returns a substring of the input string according to the semantics of method substring() of the Java class java.lang.String, provided that beginIndex is not greater than the last index of the input string and that endIndex is not less than beginIndex.
If beginIndex is greater than the last index of the input string, an empty string is returned.
If endIndex is less than beginIndex, an empty string is returned.
fn:substringAfter returns a subset of a string following a specific substring.
fn:substringAfter has two arguments.
The string argument is of type String.
If string is null, it is processed as an empty string
The substring argument is of type String.
If substring is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The result is of type String.
The substring returned starts at the first character after the substring matched in the input string, and extends up to the end of the input string.
If the string argument is an empty string, an empty string is returned
If the substring argument is an empty string, it matches the beginning of the input string and the input string is returned.
If the substring argument does not occur in the input string, an empty string is returned.
fn:substringBefore returns a subset of a string before a specific substring.
fn:substringBefore has two arguments.
The string argument is of type String.
If string is null, it is processed as an empty string
The substring argument is of type String.
If substring is null, it is processed as an empty string.
The result is of type String.
The substring returned starts at the first character in the input string and extends up to the character just before the substring matched in the input string.
If the string argument is an empty string, an empty string is returned
If the substring argument is an empty string, it matches the beginning of the input string and the input string is returned.
If the substring argument does not occur in the input string, an empty string is returned.
fn:toLowerCase converts all of the characters of a string to lower case.
fn:toLowerCase has a single argument of type String.
The result is a String in which all of the characters of the input string are converted to lower case according to the semantics of method toLowerCase() of the Java class java.lang.String.
If string is null, it is treated as an empty string and an empty string is returned
fn:toUpperCase converts all of the characters of a string to upper case.
fn:toUpperCase has a single argument of type String.
The result is a String in which all of the characters of the input string are converted to upper case according to the semantics of method toUpperCase() of the Java class java.lang.String.
If string is null, it is treated as an empty string and an empty string is returned
fn:trim removes white space from both ends of a string.
fn:trim has a single argument of type String
The result is a String with white space removed from both ends according to the semantics of method trim() of the Java class java.lang.String.
If string is null, it is treated as an empty string and an empty string is returned
The LocaleSupport class exposes the locale-determination logic for resource bundles through convenience methods.
getLocalizedMessage(PageContext, String) retrieves the localized message corresponding to the given key.
The given key is looked up in the resource bundle of the default I18N localization context, which is retrieved from the jakarta.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.localizationContext configuration setting.

If the configuration setting is empty, or the default I18N localization context does not contain any resource bundle, or the given key is undefined in its resource bundle, the string <key> is returned, where <key> is replaced with the given key.
getLocalizedMessage(PageContext, String, String) retrieves the localized message corresponding to the given key.
The given key is looked up in the resource bundle with the given base name.
If no resource bundle with the given base name exists, or the given key is undefined in the resource bundle, the string <key> is returned, where <key> is replaced with the given key.
getLocalizedMessage(PageContext, String, Object[]) retrieves the localized message corresponding to the given key, and performs parametric replacement using the arguments specified via args.
The localized message is retrieved as in getLocalizedMessage(pageContext, key)
getLocalizedMessage(PageContext, String, Object[], String) retrieves the localized message corresponding to the given key, and performs parametric replacement using the arguments specified via args.
The localized message is retrieved as in getLocalizedMessage(pageContext, key, basename)
